Journal Story:
A long-time dream is about to come true. An adventure I have been planning and preparing for over the last several months. On April 16, I'll embark on the five-month hike on the Appalachian Trail—2,190 miles from Springer Mountain, Georgia to Mount Katahdin, Maine. 
My initial plan was to hike alone. Then I remembered that my friend Dan and I had once discussed hiking the Appalachian Trail a few years ago. I texted him last fall asking if he still wanted to do the AT. Apparently, earlier that same day, he and his brother had been talking about just that, while hiking in Washington state, where he now lives. He had to give it more thought. A few days later, he texted a picture of his new hiking shoes: "I'm in." We'll have more company along the way—a couple friends, my daughter, and son are planning to meet us on the trail at different locations. 
It's a big deal to up and leave for five months. I'm thankful to have the support of my wife, Whitney, and the encouragement of my family and friends. I'm a lucky guy.

“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

We're off! 
We started our hike in Amicalola Falls State Park, Georgia. This is where the "approach trail" to the Appalachian Trail (A.T.) begins. It's a 8.8-mile trail to the top of Springer Mountain (elevation: 3,782 ft.), which is the official starting point of the A.T. The approach trail was originally part of the A.T. in the 1930s, and besides, what's an extra 8.8 miles when we are about to do 2,190! I'm hiker number 2259 and Dan is 2260. 4,000 hikers are expected on the trail this year, and according to past statistics, only 25% will finish. 
Last night we stayed in a lodge in the state park. The sound of a cold, hard wind blowing outside kept me awake. The temperature was 31°F when we started at 8:21 this morning; it's another chilly and windy day with a high of 45°F. 
The approach trail began with 604 stair steps up the face of the Amicalola waterfall. With my 37-lb backpack, it was quite a challenge! After that, we had rolling hills, terrain with moderate climbs. Then, 2.5 miles in, it began to sleet and snow. We got to Springer Mountain at 12:40 p.m.--the official start. From there, we continued to Stover Creek shelter, making today's hike a total of 11.6 miles. 
We met a few people today, from Chicago, Texas, New Orleans, and other places. And found one gentleman sitting with his head down who said, "Don't talk to me!". Apparently he was having an existential crisis. Weird. 
A freezing night here in the Stover Creek camp ground, only able to sleep a little. We expect it to warm up soon.

A beautiful day! It warmed up to 70°F, (after a freezing cold morning). Today we left Stover Creek shelter and hiked 12.9 miles to the Gooch Mountain shelter. It was very scenic and we saw several mountains--that is, we'd finish going down one mountain and then see another we'd have to go up. This is what they call P.U.D.S, "Pointless Ups and Downs". But it is really very pretty. 
We stopped at a couple rivers to replenish our water supply. Since it was warm today we got pretty thirsty, but there is plenty to drink. We came across a lot of people on the trail, and are spending the night among a group of about 20 here in the shelter and nearby tents. 
Nice day today and tomorrow should be just as nice!

“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

Today was a mountainous hike from the Gooch Mountain shelter to Neels Gap--another 15.4 miles. We started at 7:15 a.m. (earlier than usual because we knew today's hike would be an arduous one), and finished at 3:45 p.m. 
In the afternoon, we crossed Blood Mountain (elevation: 4,457 ft.) Blood Mountain is an appropriately named peak. It was tough going up; it was tough coming down. Back when I was reading about this trip, in the comfort of my own home, I read that 25% of A.T. hikers quit by Neels Gap and I always wondered why. It's only 39.9 miles from our starting point, Amicalola Falls State Park, and only 31.1 miles Springer Mountain, the official starting point of the A.T. ... Well, now I know. I can understand why people would quit after all that difficult hiking and climbing, especially when the weather is so cold at the beginning. 
By midday we had excellent weather: sunny, blue skies, so whenever we got to the top of the mountains, we were treated to beautiful views. 
And tonight we sleep in a hotel. 
Charlotte, Dan's wife, who saw us off at Amicalola Falls, is staying around for our first few days. Now that we've been hiking for three days, she drove up to pick us up at Neels Gap, and took us to a hotel. (I just had a shower. Comfort.) Tomorrow morning, she'll take us back to the trail where we left off, we'll hike for two more days, then another hotel stay, and then one day of hiking and one more hotel. It's a big help, and I appreciate the effort she has put into this—thanks Charlotte! After day 6, she flies back home to Washington State and we're really on our own. 

p.s. I'm adding more photos each day, click on Photos on the left to see the whole gallery. There is also a Guestbook where you can sign and leave me a message. :)

Last night we stayed at a Best Western in Blairsville, GA, a quaint southern town. I had a big burger and french fries for dinner--oh that was so delicious--and then all-you-can-eat breakfast at the hotel--waffles, eggs....... needless to say, we ate quite a bit before heading back out to the trail. 
As I looked at the plan for today all I saw were mountains and gaps--up a mountain, down a mountain, gap, up, down gap... and so on. But a couple interesting things happened along the trail. At 8:20 this morning we had picked back up at Neels Gap. Gap, which means, we started out uphill. It was 55°F and the wind was blowing close to 30mph. That all made it... not too much fun. We had to bundle up to stay warm but the funny thing is, on one side of the mountain it's windy and cold, then on the other side: no wind, and you're facing the sun, which is always welcome.Along the way, we found this... display, right on the side of the trail at the foot of a tree, (see photo), then later on, we experienced our first *Trail Magic.* Trail magic is when people show up at some part of the trail, usually where it meets a road, and set up a camper or van or table with all kinds of food and candy just for thru-hikers (thru-hikers are hikers who intend to make it the entire A.T., like us!). It's all free, so we took advantage, had some drinks and candies and took a break before heading back up the next mountain. We reached our destination: Lower Gap shelter, a total of 11.5 miles later, at about 1:20 p.m. We made good time today, getting in earlier than expected. We found a place to set up our tents and relax in camp for the rest of the day. We've been through cold weather up here so far, and hear that the temperature is supposed to go down to freezing tonight, to which we say.... BRING IT ON!

It was hard to get up from my nice warm spot in the tent this morning. We got up early, 6:00 a.m., ready to head out by 7, and hike the 9.7 miles to Unicoi Gap. As we left the shelter and began our ascent, we saw the most beautiful sunrise right above the mountain. You could see the sunlight reflect off the other mountains behind. The green of the trees against the golden glow of the sun was amazing. No picture would do this justice. We looked. We enjoyed. We continued on, and witnessed the sunrise again over a second higher mountain. 
At Unicoi gap, at noon, Charlotte picked us up to take us into the town of Hiawassee, GA to ressuply. We went immediately to a mexican restaurant. Then, after cleaning up and resting in the hotel room... we pigged out again at the Hawg Wild BBQ and Catfish House. Now we're getting ready to go to sleep before another early start. Tomorrow we will "slack pack"—that is, leave our backpacks behind and just carry lunch and water. It will be our longest day—16.7 miles, but without the heavy pack, should be great.

We started from Unicoi Gap at 7:40 a.m. and hiked all the way to Dicks Creek Gap by 2:24 p.m. for a total of 16.7 miles. Since this was our slack pack day, it was great! Whenever we saw a mountain coming up, we didn't think twice—no 35-lb backpack to haul up this time. We hiked about a mile with a volunteer from a group in Georgia who helps maintain the trail. Cool! And later on, in a clearing, we met Keith, who was there with his wife, providing *Trail Magic!*—an assortment of hot and cold drinks and goodies to eat. It's always nice to see that, and it's awesome of him to be out here on this windy, chilly day. We stopped and chatted with him for a bit. Thanks Keith! Overall, an uneventful day of great hiking and beautiful vistas. Charlotte was waiting for us at the end of today's hike, and now I'm in a hotel with my legs up on a pillow, resting before dinner.

Today we are taking an unplanned zero. A "zero day," as you might guess, is a day on which you do no hiking. Strong thunderstorms and heavy winds have moved in. Last night we knew there might be some weather, but still planned to leave in the morning. Then at breakfast I said to Dan, "What's plan B?". He said "Let me get my coffee, then we'll talk about it." Dan had been up at 2:00 a.m. already thinking about this. At first we considered hiring a car service to pick us up later in the day so we could slack pack, but without cell-phone coverage there would be too much risk missing the meeting point/not being able to contact the driver, and being stranded without our supplies. And we looked at the radar and forecast, and decided it was too dangerous to be out there at all, especially when the storm is more extreme up on the mountains. 
So as I sit here in the hotel, some thoughts about the A.T. so far:When we started, back at the lodge at Amicalola Falls, there was a 3-story tall map of the entire A.T. in the lobby. On day one I knew what I was getting into, but standing at the bottom floor looking up at the end point I thought-- "holy moly that is so far away!" ... And I was excited. Excitement got us up those first 604 steps. Excitement helped us set up camp after that first cold and snowy day. Every night as we arrive at our campsite after a long, tiring hike, we think, "I could be home in bed right now, instead I'm freezing in the woods, what are we doing here?!" Then I fall asleep, wake up the next morning, and have the answer. It's awesome being on the trail. So beautiful. Often while we're hiking we're just looking down, being careful where we step, and we have to remind ourselves to look up, look left, look right, so we don't miss the beauty that is all around. So, we get up, get hiking, warm up. Then go through the cycle again. 
I consider myself to be physically fit, and mentally strong, and hiking the A.T. takes both, (more-so the latter). By the second day, my body started asking, "What are you doing to me?!" My shoulder aches, though I keep adjusting the straps on the backpack; my left knee is tired of coming down steep hills; my right calf.... Suffice it to say, the body is complaining. As a long-distance runner, I expected this, and am able to manage it. As the days go on I feel stronger. After five days of hiking, 78 miles covered, I'm feeling good. 
Tomorrow by 9:00 a.m. the worst of the storm will have passed, and we'll trek on, taking it easy if need be. Every mile is one closer to our destination. There will be miserable days, there will be awe-inspiring days, and through it all, I'm enjoying this.

We got up, went for breakfast at the lodge and checked the weather: two more days of rain. Having already taken a zero yesterday because of heavy rain and wind, we decided to go. John, a resident of Hiawassee had a van service that took us back to the trail for a fee, and we picked back up at Dicks Creek Gap at 8:50 a.m. On the way to Standing Indian Shelter, we will get to North Carolina. Yay! One state down, 13 more to go! We were welcomed to NC by a doozy of a climb. It was harder still since it rained all day. After 16.7 miles, the usual: set up camp, cook, eat, go to sleep.

p.s. Sorry for the delay in updates, there's no wifi in the woods! I'll be catching up over the next couple days.

Today we go from Standing Indian Shelter to Long Branch Shelter: 16.3 miles. Also in the rain.
So far, I have made three mistakes. The worst was coming out of the shelter back to the trail—we made a wrong turn and it was about 2 miles before re realized; thats 4 additional miles today. We'd previously agreed that the person following should double check the turns, so this one's on me.
A couple days ago, I was cooking mashed potatoes, and was hungry so I reached over for tuna to mix in and accidentally knocked over the pot. This little stove is pretty unstable so just barely touching it, it goes down. No dinner that night! Then, when trying to inflate the airpad, I noticed it was taking too long... because I hadn't plugged in the hole that lets the air out. Welp, I will be making a lot more. Onward!

Long Branch Shelter to Siler Bald Shelter: 11.4 miles. The rain stopped and today was partly cloudy which made for a better hike. We tried to stay in a shelter for the first time. A shelter is a structure with three walls and a roof and floor, where hikers can sleep, one next to the other. This shelter accommodated eight people. One of them was called Fright Train (his trail name), and soon it was easy to figure out why. Freight Train is the loudest snorer I have ever heard! Dan left the shelter and set up his own tent in order to sleep. I, on the other hand, decided to stick it out, too tired to set up my tent. What. A. Mistake. Barely slept last night.

Today was a long day—17.4 miles from Siler Bald Shelter to Wesser Bald Shelter. Long, especially since it rained and rained and of course it was cold cold rain. The trail was slippery with water running down it. Socks, shoes, everything wet. I slipped and fell about three times. Not a good day. Tent, dinner, sleep. It was particularly nice to get in the tent tonight. The rain continued but I didn't care since I was warm in my sleeping bag.

Today was a short day—6.7 miles from Wessar Bald Shelter to the Nantahala Outdoor Center (NOC)—but a hard downhill, and we couldn't wait to get to NOC for a burger and fries. Oh boy, burger and fries never tasted so good! We will spend the night here in a motel for supplies, showers, and laundry. Looks like the next few days will be sunny. Finally, nice hiking weather.

This morning at the NOC, we got up, had a good breakfast—french toast, potatoes, and hot chocolate for me, and eggs, hashbrowns, toast, and *tons of coffee* for Dan—and headed out for a beautiful sunny day of hiking... and quite a climb. We went from an altitude of 1,732 ft to 5,062 ft in four hours. Cheoah Bald is the name of the peak. From there a few more ups and downs til we got to the shelter at Brown Fork Gap. Since it was so nice out, we actually hiked 5 more miles than planned, for a total of 16 miles.

Today we woke up early, and it was really cold out—low- to mid- 30s. But no cold rain! :D The chilly morning turned into another beautiful, sunny day. We continued on an uneventful 12-mile descent from yesterday's peak down toward Fontana Village. We were looking forward to getting there for a re-supply. A clear view of Fontana Dam from the trail gave the illusion that we were always so near, so it felt like forever. From our stopping point on the trail, we were going to call for a car into town, when a guy named Two Sticks, (he hiked the AT last year), came by and offered to take us to our lodge. Thanks for the lift! 
Tomorrow we'll be taking a zero before we enter into Great Smoky Mountain National Park, the location of four of the tallest mountains on the AT. We'll get enough supplies for the next five days, and have plenty to eat before heading back out. The trail picks up again with another big climb, up to 4,400 ft. p.s. Thank you everyone who has been commenting! Your encouraging words help us a lot, keep 'em coming! Once we're in the Smokys there is definitely no connectivity, so the next entries will take a while. Stay tuned!

Change of plan—today we did a nero. According to most hikers, a "nero" is when you hike less than three or four miles. We hiked without our packs from the lodge to the Fontana Dam, and saw a video about how the dam was constructed at the visitor's center. Then, we did our supply shopping, and eating. Tomorrow: into the Smokys!
By the way, curious about anything I haven't been talking about? Feel free to use the guest book (link to the left) to ask us questions! We're happy to answer them as we can.

Yesterday, we hiked a short distance to reduce the length of the today's hike. Unfortunately, the shuttle that was supposed to take us back to the trailhead was out for service, so we had to walk from Fontana Village, adding unplanned miles. We went from the lodge—after a big breakfast as usual when leaving town—and hiked to Spence Field shelter, for a total of 17.8 miles. After crossing the dam, we took a right and came up to the entrance to the Great Smoky Mountain National Park (GSMNP). The the start of the GSMNP portion of the trail rises from an elevation of 1,700 ft. to 4,520 ft. Then some ups and downs to the shelter at 4,114 ft. It went better than I expected—the rest day we just had really helped. We stayed at the shelter as required by GSMNP regulations. It was pretty busy there and we met a few people before "the event". 
That evening, somebody shouted, "Bear!" There was one close to the shelter. Two people who were out in a tent came rushing in, and a few people from the shelter ran out to scare it away. I—like most of the other hikers—was already in bed, so I didn't see it. Our only bear event so far.

A warm and sunny day here on the AT. We hiked from Spence Fields shelter to Double Spring Gap shelter for a total of 13.5 miles. Lots of ups and downs made for slow going, and it felt a lot harder than yesterday. By the time we got to the shelter we were spent, ready to eat and go to bed. We've been meeting all kinds of really nice people on the trail—Tadpole, Medusa, Rattlesnake, Not Yet, Spoon, LostandFound—folks from Australia, Sweden, the Netherlands, England, and different states in the U.S. We all get together in the evening at the shelter for cooking and chatting. It's fun to learn what other people's reasons are for hiking the AT.

Another sunny day, another 13.6 miles, from Double Spring Gap shelter to Icewater Spring shelter. Quite a few achievements today. We reached the highest point on the AT—Clingmans Dome, elevation: 6,644 ft. From up there we could see so far in every direction. Beautiful. We also crossed into Tennessee. The AT follows the North Carolina/Tennessee border, so sometimes we're in one state, and then we're in the other one; it will be like that for a while. And finally, we completed 10% of the trail, which means.... we have 90% to go!

To answer your questions so far... 
Yes! We've seen snakes, deer, chipmunks, rabbits, squirrels, and birds (in many pretty colors), and we hear about bear sightings but have yet to see one. 
Dan has a trail name! Seatac, after his home-base airport in Seattle. 
The toughest part of the trail has been Albert mountain, (elevation: 5,200 ft), back in Georgia. We're climbing more and bigger mountains here in the Smokys, but maybe we got used to it because that early one was the hardest. No issues with altitude, though.
I am most sore in the shoulders. My feet are fine! The tape really helps prevent blisters. 
We've crossed paths with a lot of hikers but never stay with a group, everyone continues at their own pace. We only chat with others in the shelters. 
I'm sleeping well. We're so tired when we get to camp we pass right out, even when there are other people around. 
We will just miss the Appalachian Trail Days Festival in Damascus (Virginia), but that's ok, we're here to hike, not party.

A great 12.6-mile hike from from Icewater Spring shelter to Tricorner Knob shelter on another nice, sunny day. There were beautiful views on either side along the ridge. As is becoming our usual day, as soon as we get to the shelter, we scout for space inside, and if there is any, we layout our bed to show the spot is taken. If the shelter is full, or if we decide we want to camp, we find a flat area nearby to set up our tents and beds. Once we know where we're sleeping, we go sit, cook a meal, hang up the food bag (so bears can't get to it), and then go to bed. 'Til tomorrow!

The 15.4 miles from Tricorner Knob shelter to Davenport Gap were mostly a beautiful, usual day. Then, a couple developments. We came to Cozy Knob shelter where we had originally planned to stay and saw a note that read, "Closed due to an aggressive bear in the area." Then, we continued on to Davenport Gap, where, per a new plan, my good friend Vicki, from Florida, picked us up. More on that change of plan, tomorrow.

So here's why we were picked up yesterday.
A couple days ago I started feeling some chest discomfort. I was worried since we were in the Smokys, such an isolated part of the trail. As luck would have it, there was an ER physician in one of our shelters; I told him what I was feeling and asked his opinion. He recommended I get an EKG as soon as possible, and probably some blood tests. From that point, we knew the quickest way to do that was to exit Great Smoky Mountain National Park at Davenport Gap and go to Asheville, NC. 
My good friend Vicki happened to be there visiting her parents, so I gave her a call and she drove an hour to the trail to pick us up. Once she met us, I told her what was up, and she found a hospital in Asheville to take me to. I got my EKG and blood test, and everything was normal. The hospital staff knew I was hiking the AT and wanted to continue, so they kept me overnight for observation to be safe. 
Today, they did some additional tests including a stress test, that also didn't show anything wrong. I talked to the cardiologist around noon and asked if I should be worried. He said, as with anything, no guarantees, but he didn't see any problems. Maybe it's just all the carrying a backpack uphill. Concerned readers: all is well. :)
When I was released, Vicki picked me up and brought back my clothes which she was kind enough to clean. Then she took Dan and I to REI to resupply, then to Five Guys for the burger and fries I was craving for lunch. 
Meanwhile, Vicki's parents, Mike and Marcia have been overwhelmingly welcoming. They let Dan stay with them while I was in the hospital and had us both over today. Vicki made dinner for everyone as well. I very much appreciate her and her family for going out of their way for us. Thank you all!

This morning, Vicki drove us an hour back to the trail, and we hit the ground hiking. We went 18.1 miles from Davenport Gap to Roaring Forks shelter. The hike started with a downhill, then we crossed I-40, west of Asheville, and started a long, long climb. Even though we'd taken a zero yesterday, it was pretty hard going. And it was worth it—amazing view from Max Patch, the peak. From there, we went downhill to the shelter and settled in for the night.

A few days back, a forest fire had been reported near Hot Springs, the town we were headed toward. We'd heard that, due to the fire, 7 miles of the AT were closed and we'd have to be shuttled around it. But luckily, by the time we arrived today, the fire had been put out and we were able to go through. We hiked 17.9 miles from Roaring Forks shelter to Hot Springs and had a beautiful day with a few showers in the afternoon. There were some very long downhills, then the trail takes you right through town. We went looking for a hotel and ended up at the Magnolia Mountain Inn, an old victorian house overlooking the mountain. It's a really tiny town so we walked around looking for a restaurant: one was closed for cleaning, a second was closed for repairs. Burgers it is!

From Hot Springs, we hiked 11 miles to Spring Mountain shelter. This morning at the inn, we met Not Yet and Nick—people we've seen on the trail. We sat down together for the all-you-can-eat breakfast provided by the inn: eggs, bacon, muffins, fresh fruit, fresh squeezed orange juice. We all had multiple helpings. Then we set back out: back down the main street of town, left across a bridge over French Broad river, right to follow the river, left and then up up uphill. We came across another hiker coming down the mountain who told us, "You're going the wrong way!" He didn't mean we were lost, just that we had so much left to climb, haha. But we knew that was the case. We ascended from 1,320 ft to 4,740 feet. Quite a climb, but fun, on a sunny, beautiful day. We also met a hiker named Fearless, a girl from Oregon, sitting by a water source. On the trail we stick to our trail names.

Today we hiked 15.9 miles from Spring Mountain shelter to Jerry Cabin shelter. The highlight was walking on an exposed hill area on a ridge. From there we could see a thunderstorm at a distance. Of course this is the worst place to be in a thunderstorm, but the sight was amazing. And at the same time, scary—there were drops on either side of the mountain. By the time we got to the shelter, the storm had passed and the skies cleared, so we set up our tents and cooked dinner. We also saw Not Yet and Nick again. All of a sudden, around 9:30 p.m., we did get a thunderstorm, with hail and heavy wind. I thought the tent was going to fly away with me in it! That was really scary, at least it only lasted half an hour. The rain stopped, back to sleep. Later on, another batch of rain, but this time not so bad! 
y not
“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

We went from Jerry Cabin shelter to Sam's Gap for a total of 17.9 miles. Today was sunny and hot which made for a tough hike. Good news: Whitney met us at the end and brought lots of goodies! Chocolates, cookies, cheesecake, fruit, cold drinks. As she waited for us to arrive, she'd been offering trail magic to other hikers and had given away some of our drinks. :p ... There were plenty left over :). She took us to a hotel for the night. 
y not
“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

Whitney drove us back to Sam's Gap for an early start. Today is a long day—just over 24 miles—but it was a slackpack which made it fun. I didn't have to carry that monster of a backpack. Especially uphill. We had a great 360° view from Big Bald Mountain; a clear day, so we could see forever. 
On the trail, we met Early Bird, another girl hiking by herself. And around the time we were looking for a spot to stop for lunch we met with trail magic! David and Janet offered a selection and I got a ham and cheese sandwich with Fritos and a cold drink. What a nice surprise! As we approached Erwin, Whitney came up to meet us on the trail so she got to hike a bit of the AT and we all went back down. She also brought some iced cold Coca Cola-- sooo good after a hot day! (not a paid endorsement). Then to the hotel for a shower, and out for pizza for dinner. 
y not
“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

Today was essentially a zero. We got up at 8 a.m., had breakfast—the usual hotel fare of sausage, egg, muffins, waffles, etc. On our resupply, we went to a store called Uncle Jonny's for freeze dried food and then Food Lion for the rest. We spent the remainder of the day repacking our bags, cleaning things up, and resting. A sunny day in town; nice to have a view of the mountains without having to climb them!

Amy and Zoey arrived last night to join us for their section of the AT, from Erwin to Damascus. Whitney took us all to the trail head this morning and we hiked for 17.1 miles from Erwin to Cherry Gap shelter. Dan and I were concerned we were going too fast for our new trail mates, but everyone enjoyed the hike. It was a hot day, with lots of uphills, but once we got to the shelter area we found a nice spot for our campsite.

Today we hiked 17.6 miles from Cherry Gap shelter to Roan High Knob shelter. Amy's leg was bothering her yesterday but after a good night sleep she was ready to go. She also didn't care for the heat but luckily today was overcast and cool. Unluckily, that turned to rain later in the day. We found trail magic!, which is always awesome, and got to have burgers and hotdogs and drinks. This was a well-placed treat, right before a big climb, which took us to the highest shelter on the AT. Once we got there, we found a nice spot for camping, had dinner, and went to sleep.

“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

It rained all night last night. And all day today. It was hard to get up this morning and pack everything without getting things wet. From Roan High Knob,  we hiked down the windy, cold, rainy mountain for 16.3 miles, to U.S. 19. On the way, we went through some balds which would have made great vistas, but all we saw today was rainclouds. We ended up in the village of Roan Mountain, TN where we found a bed & breakfast in which to spend tonight. 
y not
“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

This morning, Steve, the owner of the bed and breakfast we stayed in last night, took us back to the trail. We were concerned that it would be another rainy day but we got a beautiful morning, with rain not showing up til noon. From U.S. 19 East we headed for Moreland Gap shelter. The 18.4-mile hike was tough; the usual ups and downs felt especially difficult.
We also took a slight detour. We came across a sign that said there were waterfalls to the right off the trail--worth taking a look. Normally, hikers don't want to take a side trail because we're already walking long enough. But we went, and it was worth it. We sat there a while by the beautiful Jones Falls. We also went by a large river; watching the water flow down was another beautiful sight.
We reached our destination, and, for the first time, had a shelter all to ourselves. Tonight it rained hard, and it was nice to listen to the rain while nice and comfortable inside. 
y not
“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

From Moreland Gap Shelter, we hiked 14.8 miles to the Shook Road Boots-Off hostel. A particularly scenic hike. The weather was nice--a little bit of rain, but overall the overcast sky made for a nice, cool day. Helpful, since we went over more hills today. Amy and Zoey have been killing the uphills! so we've let them take the lead. While Dan and I have been out here four weeks and have our "hiking legs", the one thing they have on us is age. They can take the uphills much faster than we, or I can, (I hope I'm not slowing Dan down!). They let us catch up at the top and then keep going. 
We saw several more waterfalls today, and crossed some bridges over a river in Tennessee. It's really pretty being out in the middle of nowhere with trees and greenery all around. We came across one section with a 2-ft-wide ledge we had to pass through. On one side: huge rock, on the other: river. Zoey was in the lead when she stopped, froze, and came running back. "Snake!" There was a rattlesnake sitting there, and no way around it. Dan said, "I'll take care of this!" and with his hiking poles, tried to grab and push the snake off the ledge. He pushed it into the water and we watched it swim to a rock, then back across the river to the other side. They are quite the swimmers! 
At the end of the day, when we got to the hostel, they took us to McDonalds for dinner and the Dollar Store for a resupply. Ready to get going tomorrow!

We left Boots-Off hostel and hiked to Iron Mountain shelter, 16 miles away. After an initial climb from 2,100 ft to 3,600 ft, most the hike was along a long ridge. Nothing eventful happened, but we had a nice view of the lake below. When we arrived at the shelter, there was only one other person--Blasto, from Wisconsin, a retired thru-hiker who we've seen and talked with several times before. Since there was plenty of room, and we were expecting rain, we decided to stay there that night. Then, as we sat around in the shelter, Amy jumped; "Mouse!" (As it happens, a lot of the shelters have mice in them.) Then Zoey jumped; "I don't know if I want to stay here tonight!". Then it started raining. I don't think Amy slept well, thinking about the mouse, but the little guy was minding his own business and never came around. And the shelter was a great idea, it rained hard. The rest of us passed out and slept through the night. 
y not
“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

Today we hiked 15.9 miles to Abbington Gap. This has been the flattest section of the AT so far, which made for good hiking. With no climbs, we stayed at around 4,000 ft in elevation. Unlike the last few days, we arrived at a shelter full of several other people. This is likely due to Trail Days, which took place from Friday, May 18--Sunday, May 20. Trail Days is annual event that celebrates past and present AT thru-hikers. Thousands of people converge on Damascus and gather for a big to-do. Now that it's over, the shelters are crowded again. We decided to tent tonight. Fortunately there was no rain, so it worked out well. 
y not
“Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.”—Mark Twain

From Abbington Gap to Damascus, we hiked 10 miles. This was a relatively downhill stretch into town. Dan and I made an early start, leaving 40 minutes before Amy and Zoey since they are the stronger hikers. We all arrived in Damascus within 10 minutes of each other. While waiting for them, we were laying down on the ground, when a guy who lived nearby came over with a couple beers, figuring we were thirsty. Needless to say, I gave my beer to Dan. After that, we went to a restaurant, Mojo's, and had a really good lunch.Zoey, trail name: Mountain Goat, (because of how easily she went up hills), and Amy, a.k.a. Granny, (not that she wasn't keeping up with Zoey, it's a trail name she had from before), ended their section hike here—126.7 miles from Erwin, TN to Damascus, VA. Today they go home. And I'll be catching a ride with them; going home too. More on that in my next post!

Dear family, friends and followers of this AT Journal,
After 5 weeks and 480 miles of hiking, we have arrived in Damascus, VA, at which point I have decided to end my journey. As you know, back in Asheville, I had to go to the hospital to have the discomfort in my chest checked out. Even though the cardiologist didn’t find anything, he couldn’t make any guarantees about my continued wellbeing on the trail. At that point, I decided to get back on the trail to see how things would feel. I noticed that things weren’t getting worse, nor were they getting better, especially on the more difficult climbs. I set Damascus as a goal, it seemed like a logical place to stop.
As you all know, my friend Dan was hiking with me. He has decided to continue the hike towards Katahdin. I feel bad abandoning him, but feel like I need to put my health first. I don’t think what I was feeling is anything to mess around with considering how isolated we sometimes were on the trail. I wish Dan all the best and I’ll be tracking his progress. 
Thank you to all our followers for your words of encouragement and good wishes. This has been an amazing journey. Before I set out in April, I didn’t quite know what to expect. It has surpassed all expectations — from the people I met on the trail, seeing spring unfold, the variety of vegetation we saw as we climbed, to the stunning vistas. Time seems to run slower on the trail. Even though it’s only been 5 weeks, it seems like it’s been much longer than that. You lose all concept of time and your brain isn’t overwhelmed with the intricacies of daily life. If you were to ask me if I’d do it again, my answer would be an overwhelming “yes."
